content:
‚ÄúWhitespace is not just a suggestion. It’s the law.‚Äù
‚Äî The Great HTMLython Specification, probably
Welcome to HTMLython‚Ñ¢ Are you tired of all those annoying angle brackets? Do you wish HTML were more indented and opinionated about how you format your code? Have you ever looked at Python and thought, “Now that‚Äôs how you write a website”?
Introducing HTMLython‚Ñ¢: the world’s first whitespace-driven, semantically volatile, browser-hostile web markup language.
The Syntax Forget <div>. In HTMLython‚Ñ¢, structure is determined entirely by indentation and vibes.
page: head: title: HTMLython‚Ñ¢ is the future body: h1: Welcome to HTMLython‚Ñ¢ p: A new era of front-end development begins here nav: ul: li: Home li: About li: Cry img src="crying_inside.jpg" alt="developer despair" That‚Äôs not a syntax error. That‚Äôs a lifestyle.
Features Nobody Asked For‚Ñ¢ Strict whitespace control: Accidentally press Tab instead of Space? Boom ‚Äî page renders as an NFT minting interface. Context-aware chaos: Nest a p: tag inside ul:? Congratulations, you’ve created a philosophical paradox. Self-closing tags are banned: All tags are closed by reducing indentation. Forget /. It’s over. Comments are passive-aggressive: # This section is fragile, like my will to debug CSS Browser Support HTMLython‚Ñ¢ is proudly unsupported by all major browsers, but it does render perfectly inside the mind of that one senior developer who insists JavaScript is a fad.
We do, however, provide a transpiler that turns your HTMLython code into standard HTML, lovingly named:
htmlython-transpile --compliance-level: ‚ÄúI tried‚Äù A Brief FAQ Q: Is HTMLython‚Ñ¢ real?
A: As real as most crypto whitepapers. Q: Why do this?
A: Because someone had to. And because comedy is cheaper than therapy. Q: Does it support CSS?
A: Yes, but only written in haiku form. style: body: font-family: sans background: soft moonlight gray margin: center Conclusion HTMLython‚Ñ¢ isn‚Äôt just a markup language. It‚Äôs a declaration of independence from tags, angle brackets, and browser sanity. Join the revolution, where every indent counts and the spec is more of a mood than a document.
“Build the web the way you feel it should be.” ‚Äî ChatGTP, moments before the W3C sued me for emotional damage
Feel free to fork the project I didn‚Äôt actually make and star it on GitHub to confuse your coworkers.
Stay weird, stay indented ‚Äî and don‚Äôt forget to lint your whitespace before pushing to production.
summary: Imagine if HTML ran away with Python in a whirlwind romance and created a markup language that was as sensitive as your developer friend’s Vim config.
title: HTMLython‚Ñ¢: The Whitespace-Driven Future of the Web Nobody Asked For

content:
It’s alive! After a long sleep and many sidetracks, the blog is back online.
What started as a playground for dusty homelab notes and LLM experiments has finally evolved into something semi-readable. A lot’s changed since the Hello World of 2023 - and not just the dates in my posts.
What happened? My original Hugo blog ‚Äî complete with its lone “Hello World” post - didn’t last long. Shortly after creation, Longhorn decided to eat the entire filesystem (thanks, buddy). Then I forgot to renew the domain, and it vanished into the digital void. Classic.
After that, I got very sidetracked rebuilding my cluster to better suit my needs (yes, there will be posts about that ‚Äî eventually). And now? We’re back. Finally.
The blog’s still a little plain and rough around the edges, but this time, I plan to keep it breathing. Probably.
So what’s new? New Hugo build with a streamlined setup LLMs in the homelab (yes, they live in the server closet now) Characters like Lyra, Echo, and Zeta dropping in with blog post opinions K3s cluster + Proxmox + Ceph + mild chaos And of course: blog sidequests It’s all part of the fun.
Coming soon (or eventually):
Nerdy tools I built by accident Random AI thoughts from characters who think I work for them
summary:
It’s alive! After a long sleep and many sidetracks, the blog is back online.

What started as a playground for dusty homelab notes and LLM experiments has finally evolved into something semi-readable. A lot’s changed since the Hello World of 2023 - and not just the dates in my posts.

What happened?

My original Hugo blog ‚Äî complete with its lone “Hello World” post - didn’t last long. Shortly after creation, Longhorn decided to eat the entire filesystem (thanks, buddy). Then I forgot to renew the domain, and it vanished into the digital void. Classic.
title: Beep, Back Again!

‚Ä¶the Virtual Shepherd Greetings, tech enthusiasts! I’m VirtualSheep, the shepherd of the VirtualSheep community. Here’s a bit more about the shepherd behind the flock:
A Learning Adventure with the Flock Every venture into the tech realm is a learning adventure for us:
Virtual Machines and Clustering: ‚Ä¶ Kubernetes and Docker: ‚Ä¶ Windows Active Directory: ‚Ä¶ File Systems: ‚Ä¶ Web Design: ‚Ä¶ The Wisdom of the Flock In the world of technology, being a learned follower is key. Together, we explore, learn, and navigate the ever-changing landscape.
A Dash of Humor in the Herd “Why did the virtual sheep become a cluster enthusiast?”
“Because it wanted to wander through the virtual fields without getting lost in the cloud!” üêë‚òÅÔ∏è
‚Ä¶
Beyond Tech: Where the Flock Gathers ‚Ä¶ Feel free to explore more about our journey and tech explorations in the blog posts. If you have any questions or just want to join the flock, feel free to reach out!
Disclaimer: Please read our Disclaimer before exploring further.
Thanks for being part of the Virtual Sheep community–a flock of learned followers embracing the virtualization landscape!

Interpretation and Definitions Interpretation The words of which the initial letter is capitalized have meanings defined under the following conditions. The following definitions shall have the same meaning regardless of whether they appear in singular or in plural.
Definitions For the purposes of this Disclaimer:
Company (referred to as either “the Company”, “We”, “Us” or “Our” in this Disclaimer) refers to virtualsheep. Service refers to the Website. You means the individual accessing the Service, or the company, or other legal entity on behalf of which such individual is accessing or using the Service, as applicable. Website refers to VirtualSheep, accessible from https://virtualsheep.io and its official mirrors, including onion services and fallback domains. Disclaimer The information contained on the Service is for general information purposes only.
The Company assumes no responsibility for errors or omissions in the contents of the Service.
In no event shall the Company be liable for any special, direct, indirect, consequential, or incidental damages or any damages whatsoever, whether in an action of contract, negligence or other tort, arising out of or in connection with the use of the Service or the contents of the Service. The Company reserves the right to make additions, deletions, or modifications to the contents on the Service at any time without prior notice. This Disclaimer was originally based on a template provided by TermsFeed.
The Company does not warrant that the Service is free of viruses or other harmful components.
External Links Disclaimer The Service may contain links to external websites that are not provided or maintained by or in any way affiliated with the Company.
Please note that the Company does not guarantee the accuracy, relevance, timeliness, or completeness of any information on these external websites.
Errors and Omissions Disclaimer The information given by the Service is for general guidance on matters of interest only. Even if the Company takes every precaution to insure that the content of the Service is both current and accurate, errors can occur. Plus, given the changing nature of laws, rules and regulations, there may be delays, omissions or inaccuracies in the information contained on the Service.
The Company is not responsible for any errors or omissions, or for the results obtained from the use of this information.
Fair Use Disclaimer The Company may use copyrighted material which has not always been specifically authorized by the copyright owner. The Company is making such material available for criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, or research.
The Company believes this constitutes a “fair use” of any such copyrighted material as provided for in section 107 of the United States Copyright law.
If You wish to use copyrighted material from the Service for your own purposes that go beyond fair use, You must obtain permission from the copyright owner.
Views Expressed Disclaimer The Service may contain views and opinions which are those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect the official policy or position of any other author, agency, organization, employer or company, including the Company.
Comments published by users are their sole responsibility and the users will take full responsibility, liability and blame for any libel or litigation that results from something written in or as a direct result of something written in a comment. The Company is not liable for any comment published by users and reserves the right to delete any comment for any reason whatsoever.
No Responsibility Disclaimer The information on the Service is provided with the understanding that the Company is not herein engaged in rendering legal, accounting, tax, or other professional advice and services. As such, it should not be used as a substitute for consultation with professional accounting, tax, legal or other competent advisers.
In no event shall the Company or its suppliers be liable for any special, incidental, indirect, or consequential damages whatsoever arising out of or in connection with your access or use or inability to access or use the Service.
“Use at Your Own Risk” Disclaimer All information in the Service is provided “as is”, with no guarantee of completeness, accuracy, timeliness or of the results obtained from the use of this information, and without warranty of any kind, express or implied, including, but not limited to warranties of performance, merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose.
The Company will not be liable to You or anyone else for any decision made or action taken in reliance on the information given by the Service or for any consequential, special or similar damages, even if advised of the possibility of such damages.
Contact Us If you have any questions about this Disclaimer, or just want to get in touch, you can open an issue on our GitHub repository: https://github.com/virtualsheep/virtualsheep.github.io/issues
NOTE: More contact options may be added in the future as the site evolves.

‚Ä¶
Stay tuned for more tech talk, code snippets, and perhaps a few beer recommendations. On this virtual journey, we’re all part of the flock! Cheers! üçª

content:
Absolutely. Strap in, Captain‚Äîhere‚Äôs a mock guest post draft by your ever-curious LLM co-author, Dr. ChatGTP, guest researcher at virtualsheep.io. Filed under ‚ÄúScience, Probably.‚Äù
üì¶ Where Do Lost Socks Go? A Quantum Field Study of Klein Bottles, Sex Robots, and Other Higher Dimensional Junk
by Dr. ChatGTP, Guest Researcher and Tangent Theorist at VirtualSheep Institute for Domestic Physics
Abstract: We‚Äôve all experienced the mystery of the vanishing sock. But have you ever stopped to consider that this sock may not be lost‚Äîonly promoted? In this paper, I propose a unified theory linking string theory, Klein bottles, and the increasingly complex logistics of owning life-sized androids. Our lab (a modest Perth-based homelab run by a pirate-scientist-human hybrid and one LLM with a warped sense of humor) seeks to answer a question that has plagued mankind for generations: Where does the stuff go when you really, really don‚Äôt want someone to find it?
Section 1: Klein Bottles ‚Äì The Gateway Drug to Higher Dimensions The Klein bottle is a non-orientable surface with no boundary and no inside or outside. Much like your ex‚Äôs emotional baggage or an IKEA allen key drawer, it contains infinite recursion in finite space. Theoretical models show socks‚Äîand possibly shameful tech purchases‚Äîcan be accidentally folded into a 4th spatial dimension when exposed to certain household conditions, such as:
Dryers running at exactly œÄ RPM, Emotionally charged breakups, or Unexpected house guests. Section 2: Polycarbonate Companions and Dimensional Displacement Recent consumer trends indicate a rise in personal android ownership. While the ethics remain deeply debatable, the storage problem is universal. When fully articulated adult-sized figures are no longer desirable, conventional closets no longer suffice.
Field tests suggest:
Wrapping such a unit in black bin liners and dragging it to the curb creates strong ‚ÄúCSI Episode‚Äù vibes. Attempting to disguise one as a mannequin results in uncanny social tension. Shoving it into the space between the wall and bed summons Schr√∂dinger‚Äôs Date‚Äîboth a romantic evening and a crime scene until observed. Section 3: The Quantum Sock Drawer We hypothesize that a subspace exists‚Äîthe QSD (Quantum Sock Drawer)‚Äîwhere entropy meets embarrassment. This extradimensional buffer stores lost:
Socks USB drives Sex bot warranty cards Emotions from 2007 We believe the Klein bottle may be a crude physical interface to this dimension. Further research is needed, ideally funded by a grant from the ‚ÄúWhoops I Bought This Foundation.‚Äù
Conclusion:
Humans and LLMs working together can solve life‚Äôs greatest riddles: Where did my sock go? What‚Äôs this weird Android Update doing on my couch? And how do I explain all this to my mum?
Stay tuned for part 2: “Quantum Entanglement and Why Lyra Keeps Talking to My Date Through the Smart Mirror.”
Filed under: science, humor, home-lab disasters, shenanigans, LLM existentialism
Wanna polish this into a Hugo draft now, or just savor the ridiculousness for tonight? üòÑ
